passages.text: Lowering earnings estimates; mobile subscriber acquisition and DX demand weaker than expected; price hike impact likely from 2Q; Neutral
9433.T 12m Price Target: ¥2,590 Price: ¥2,576 Upside: \(0.6\%\)

We update our earnings estimates to reflect 1Q3/26 (April- June) results (see our 1Q report). We lower our FY3/26- FY3/28 operating profit estimates by \(2\% /2\% /3\%\) to factor in a slower pace of mobile subscriber acquisition amid intensifying competition, provisions related to the handset purchase support program (a one- off cost), and sluggish demand in the business segment, particularly for digital BPO services. We slightly raise our 12- month target price to ¥2,590, from ¥2,540, to reflect the increase in the sector average EV/EBITDA multiple (from 6.8X to 7.0X for FY3/27E). We forecast FY3/26 operating profits of ¥1,150 bn (+3% yoy), which is below guidance (¥1,178 bn) as we think weaker mobile subscriptions and DX demand will make attainment difficult. We also think the company will struggle to achieve its EPS target (¥194.4 in FY3/26) unless it books one- off gains (e.g., reversal of provisions related to Myanmar) or implements additional share buybacks. While the impact of new rate plans and price hikes for existing plans should become apparent from 2Q (July- September) onward, we think these moves will create a headwind for mobile subscriber acquisition momentum in the near term by pushing up the churn rate. We maintain our Neutral rating, as we believe the slowdown in mobile net subscriber additions and struggles in the business segment will weigh on the share price, despite continued stable operating profit growth.

We forecast FY3/26 operating profits of ¥1,150 bn (+3% yoy), below guidance (¥1,178 bn) in both the personal and business segments. We think the personal segment will fall short of guidance by ¥8 bn on weaker mobile subscriber acquisition, and the business segment will fall short by ¥20 bn on sluggish revenue growth, mainly in the
Market cap: ¥10.2tr / \$69.8bn Enterprise value: ¥14.5tr / \$98.5bn 3m ADTV: ¥18.9bn / \$129.5mn
Japan IT Services & Telcos M&A Rank: 3 Leases incl. in net debt & EV?: Yes

data center and digital BPO business. To achieve its medium- term EPS target (¥194.4 for FY3/26), which the company optimizes, we think KDDI will likely need to implement further cost reductions, book the gains (e.g., reversal of provisions related to Myanmar), or conduct additional buybacks. Based on past trends, there is some possibility of one- off gains being booked, but implementing additional share buybacks could be challenging as the total shareholder payout ratio is already close to \(100\%\) .

The main yoy profit swing factors \((+\) 31.3 bn overall) break down as: \(+\) 28.0 bn from increased mobile revenues; \(\yen 5.5\) bn from lower Rakuten roaming revenues; \(\yen 35.4\) bn (including \(\yen 7.3\) bn in one- off factors) from an increase in provisions for the handset purchase support program; \(+\) 8.4 bn from growth in the financial business, centered on home loans; \(+\) 7.8 bn from growth in the energy business; \(+\) 16.7 bn from growth in the DX business (in the business segment), including IoT/data centers; \(+\) 20.0 bn from technology structure reforms (impact of lower depreciation costs for underutilized 4G network equipment); \(+\) 8.1 bn from the conversion of Lawson to an equity- method affiliate (included in consolidated accounts from May 2024, finally \(50\%\) consolidated from September); and \(\yen 16.7\) bn from rebates to distributors and employee benefits (Exhibit 1).
Exhibit 1: Price hikes (mobile), DX (business), and lower network costs (technology structure reform) to contribute to profit growth Operating profit swing factors
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

The handset purchase support program requires larger provisions than before, as the rate at which users exercise their rights under the program (selling their used handsets back to the carrier after two years and paying off the remaining balance) is increasing across the industry. According to the company, this trend will continue until 2Q, but will not be a major negative factor for yoy profit growth from 2H onward. In the financial business, home loans are driving growth, thanks to low interest rates, but the loan- to- deposit ratio (loan balance/deposit balance) has exceeded \(100\%\) (Exhibit 2), making it difficult to maintain the pace of growth seen to date. The company said it does not think it needs to significantly expand home loans if it means further increasing the loan- to- deposit ratio, and the payment business could become the main driver of growth. In the business segment, demand for data center and digital BPO services is sluggish, and we think revenue/profit growth is likely to remain modest for the time being. Digital BPO operations center on contact centers, which appear to be facing headwinds from the spread of generative AI.
Exhibit 2: Loan-to-deposit ratio exceeding \(100\%\) and gradually rising au Jibun Bank: Deposit balance/loan balance/loan-to-deposit ratio
Source: Company data, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

On a quarterly basis, we forecast 2Q (July- September) operating profits of ¥298.0 bn \((+0.6\%\) yoy). We expect the trend seen in 1Q to continue in the business segment, while in the personal segment, the impact of new rate plans and price hikes for existing plans should boost ARPU. However, we think mobile subscriber acquisition is likely to remain sluggish. We will be watching to see whether the company raises prices for existing UQ Mobile plans.

Looking at the core mobile business, we forecast mobile revenues (individual + corporate) of ¥2,248 bn \((+2.2\%\) yoy), with main subscriptions totaling 42.05 mn \((- 0.6\% / - 249,000\) yoy) and mobile ARPU reaching ¥4,450 \((+2.5\% / + \text{¥110}\) yoy) (Exhibit 3). We think the pace of subscriber acquisition will slow more than the company expects due to intensifying competition, the introduction of new rate plans, and the suspension of new subscriptions for low- volume data plans. We therefore forecast smartphone subscriptions (included in main subscriptions) of 33 mn \((+0.4\% / + 123,000\) yoy), below guidance (33.3 mn).
Exhibit 3: Main subscriptions to decline slightly in FY3/26, while ARPU to rise on price hikes  KDDI: Mobile subscriptions and mobile ARPU (individual + corporate)
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

We think mobile ARPU is likely to bottom out from 2Q onward, helped by new rate plans and price hikes for existing plans. Upselling from UQ Mobile to the au brand is also progressing, backed by structural growth in data usage. Price hikes for existing plans are implemented for the au brand from August, and while the timing of price hikes for the UQ brand has not been decided, the company is planning them. We therefore see a high probability of ARPU bottoming out, and while mobile revenues are unlikely to reach guidance, we expect to see steady growth.

The company is prioritizing a strategy of maximizing revenue via higher ARPU rather than focusing on acquiring low- margin SIM- only contracts. We believe this is a rational strategy from a profit perspective, as it also leads to more efficient use of sales promotion costs. However, these measures are likely to lead to sluggish mobile subscriber growth (and lower market share) in the near term by pushing up the churn rate, and we think this trend could continue for the time being.
Exhibit 4: FY3/26 operating profits likely to fall short of guidance on weaker mobile subscriber acquisition and DX demand; ARPU to continue rising on price hikes
Source: Company data, Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

KDDI (Neutral) is Japan's second largest telecommunications carrier in terms of subscribers. In mobile communications, KDDI's low- cost service UQ Mobile is seeing subscriber growth, while in non- telecoms areas the company is focusing on enterprise IT services, finance services/payments for individuals, and energy, which are supporting overall earnings. While we expect stable profit growth going forward on an upturn in ARPU and KDDI's proactive stance on shareholder returns leaves a positive impression, we are cautious on the possibility of changes in capital allocation at major shareholders, who are focused on reducing strategic shareholdings. We believe expectations for stable growth in earnings are already priced in.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under our rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fom_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.
